solution_line_template: Since Mary first weighed {initial_weight} pounds, after she dropped a dozen pounds she weighed {initial_weight}-{dropped_initial}=<<{initial_weight}-{dropped_initial}={weight_after_initial_drop}>>{weight_after_initial_drop} pounds.
Twice the weight she initially lost is {dropped_initial}*{multiplier_twice}=<<{dropped_initial}*{multiplier_twice}={weight_added_back}>>{weight_added_back} pounds.

So, when she added back twice the weight that she initially lost, her weight jumped to {weight_after_initial_drop}+{weight_added_back}=<<{weight_after_initial_drop}+{weight_added_back}={weight_after_gain_back}>>{weight_after_gain_back} pounds.
Three times more than she initially had lost is {dropped_initial}*{multiplier_three_times}=<<{dropped_initial}*{multiplier_three_times}={weight_dropped_again}>>{weight_dropped_again} pounds.

Therefore, when Mary lost 3 times more than she initially lost, her weight dropped to {weight_after_gain_back}-{weight_dropped_again}=<<{weight_after_gain_back}-{weight_dropped_again}={weight_after_second_drop}>>{weight_after_second_drop} pounds.
Finally, when Mary gained back half of a dozen pounds, her final weight was {weight_after_second_drop}+{half_dozen}=<<{weight_after_second_drop}+{half_dozen}={final_weight}>>{final_weight} pounds.
